message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PCR for HIV RNA is the most accurate test to detect HIV in infants. Antigen assay for p24 and EIA for HIV antibody may not be reliable in infants due to passive transfer of maternal antibodies. Viral culture is not routinely used for HIV testing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PCR for HIV RNA is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing HIV infection in neonates and infants. It can detect HIV infection as early as 1 to 2 weeks after birth, whereas other tests may take several months to be positive. EIA for HIV antibody, antigen assay for p24, and viral culture are not as sensitive as PCR and have longer turnaround times.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HIV RNA is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing HIV infection in infants younger than 18 months of age, as they may still have passively acquired maternal antibodies which can cause false positives with other tests. Therefore, this would be the most appropriate diagnostic test to address the patient's concern about transmission to her baby.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PCR for HIV RNA is the most sensitive and specific test for HIV diagnosis and can detect HIV at an earlier stage than other tests. It is the recommended method for diagnosing HIV infection in infants born to HIV-positive mothers. EIA for HIV antibody, antigen assay for p24, and viral culture are not as reliable as PCR for detecting HIV infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HIV RNA is the most sensitive test for detecting the virus in infants born to HIV-positive mothers. It can detect the virus as early as 2-4 weeks after birth, allowing for early intervention to prevent transmission. EIA for HIV antibody, antigen assay for p24, and viral culture are all less sensitive and may not detect the virus in the early stages of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HIV RNA is the most appropriate diagnostic test for addressing the patient’s concern about transmission of HIV to her baby. It can detect the presence of the virus in the blood before the body produces antibodies against it. EIA for HIV antibody, antigen assay for p24, and viral culture are not as sensitive or specific as PCR for early detection of HIV infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PCR for HIV RNA is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing HIV infection in infants. EIA for HIV antibody is not recommended for infants under 18 months of age, as maternal antibodies can persist in their system. Antigen assay for p24 and viral culture are also not recommended for diagnosis in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the most sensitive method for detecting HIV infection and can detect the virus soon after infection. It is also recommended for early diagnosis of HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers as the virus can be transmitted during childbirth. EIA for HIV antibody, antigen assay for p24, and viral culture may not detect the virus soon after infection or in infants born to HIV-positive mothers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HIV RNA is the most sensitive and specific method for detecting HIV infection in infants. It can detect HIV RNA as early as 1-2 weeks after infection, making it the most appropriate diagnostic test for the baby after delivery. EIA for HIV antibody may not reliably detect HIV infection in infants until 18 months of age. Antigen assay for p24 and viral culture are also less sensitive and specific than PCR for detecting HIV infection in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PCR for HIV RNA is the most sensitive and specific test for detection of HIV in infants, and can detect HIV infection as early as 2-3 weeks after birth. EIA for HIV antibody would only detect maternal antibodies in the infant, which may not necessarily indicate infection. Antigen assay for p24 and viral culture have lower sensitivity compared to PCR.
